Award.AwardTitle: Genetic analysis of gamete length evolution in Drosophila
Award.AbstractNarration:
Male gametes are the most morphologically diverse cells in the animal kingdom, ranging from very simple cells to sperm with missing or multiple flagella and conjugated sperm that form cooperative units. To understand how this diversity evolved, it is necessary to investigate gamete morphology from an evolutionary developmental perspective, an approach widely applied to questions of embryonic development in whole organisms but that has never been applied to cellular morphogenesis. The proposed research will exploit the uniquely long spermatozoa in fruit flies of the genus Drosophila (up to 5.8 cm) to further investigate previously identified candidate genes for sperm length. Drosophila also present an especially elegant system due to their experimental and genetic tractability. These genes will be validated as potentially important in spermatogenesis, and their molecular evolution across the Drosophila lineage will be investigated. The research will also explore how these genes function during spermatogenesis using in vitro culture methods that allow cell development to be observed and manipulated in the controlled environment of a culture dish.

The proposed research will greatly inform the scientific community's understanding of how gamete diversity has evolved at the developmental, molecular and cellular levels. Sperm are functionally important evolutionarily (affecting reproductive fitness and speciation), as well as biomedically and economically (informing fertility and in vitro fertilization practices in humans and domestic animals). Studies of the genetics of sperm form may also improve our understanding of general flagellar and ciliary development, including ciliopathies involved in human disease (e.g., cystic fibrosis, polycystic kidney disease).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF award funded research on the genetic basis of long sperm in the fruit fly Drosophila. These tiny flies have extraordinarily long sperm – up to 5.8 cm in one species, which is over 500 times longer than human sperm. We are interested in why these sperm have evolved and how a tiny male can produce such long sperm. Like many questions about male biology, the answer to why fruit flies have giant sperm lies within the female, literally. Female fruit flies store sperm within specialized organs within their reproductive tract, and the length of the primary sperm storage organ, known as the seminal receptacle or SR, covaries with sperm length across different species of Drosophila.

One goal of this research was to identify the genetic basis of both sperm length and SR length and determine if a subset of genes controlled both traits. Instead, we found that the old adage “the best-laid plans of mice and men often go awry” also applies to flies. Our years-long effort to map the genetic basis of sperm length in D. melanogaster was foiled by a large inverted region on the third chromosome, which prevented us from narrowing down the location of specific genes. We are currently rerunning our genetic mapping experiment using a different set of flies that lack this inversion in any of the original source populations. Our results so far show that there is significant heritable genetic variation in these flies for sperm length and SR length, suggesting that mapping these traits is feasible. We also confirmed previously results that showed a genetic correlation between sperm length SR length, and we additionally found a significant genetic correlation between total sperm length and sperm head length. We expect to complete this mapping experiment over the next two years.

We were also able to identify several genes that, when disrupted, change sperm length. Interestingly, we found an additional two genes that affect SR length. We have thus far not identified genes that affect both sperm length and SR length, but further studies are underway. Two putative sperm length genes are Eip74EF and Stat92E. Eip74EF is involved in the ecdysone pathway, which controls larval molting, development, and oogenesis but has no known function in spermatogenesis. Interestingly, disruption of Eip74EF reduces sperm length but increases fecundity, suggesting a trade-off between sperm length and sperm numbers. Knockout of Stat92E has a very small but statistically significant decrease in sperm length with no effect on SR length or sperm head length. Both these studies were led by undergraduate students who are now both in medical school.
